Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed project will bring together researchers in a workshop to be held December 8-9, 2016 at the Hilton Hotel, San Francisco, CA. The Workshop will address research areas of a wide range of non-graphene 2D atomic layers such as hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), transition metal di-chalcogenides, tertiary compounds of carbo-nitrides and complex oxides, as well as their applications in various devices. It will allow scientific exchanges among leading scientists working on beyond graphene 2D materials and devices to help promote future collaborations and address common challenges. The Workshop is expected to play a key role in addressing in detail currently faced bottlenecks in 2D material and device research and identifying new directions for research. The research discussed at the Workshop is expected to lead to technological breakthroughs and disruptive technologies that can have great societal impact in the future in many areas such as sensing, communications and health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF EFRI-2DARE Grantees Meeting 2016 at San Francisco is the very first program-wide review meeting organized, following the 2015 Grantees Annual Meeting held at NSF where a representive from each team was present.  Under the NSF EFRI-2DARE program, there were 19 teams including 96 PIs and co-PIs total in US awarded in two years: 2014 and 2015.  At the 2016 SF Grantees Meeting, about 75 project participants attended the meeting; among the participants, at least the leading PI, one co-PI and one graduate student from each project team attended the 2-day event held at the Hilton Union Square, SF, CA.  Each team presented an oral talk as well as a poster during the event.  The integrated poster session, staged in the same room with the oral presentations, was highly praised since it effectively facilitated communications among teams thus fostering potential collaborations.  The requested funds supported the space rental, the meals provided at the Grantees Meeting, the A/V support and the poster session support.  At this meeting, we assmebed the national scientifc community to a common stage to share the state-of-the-art discoveries and plan for the future directios of layered materials.  The subject matter of the meeting is highly focused on layered materials: from theory to experiments, from materials to applications.  It is an especially important incentive for student and junior faculty attendence.
